text:
The magazine, which, like Vanity Fair, is owned by Conde Nast, issued an 'apology statement': "Mistakes were made."

GQ magazine has mercilessly mocked Vanity Fair's infamous photoshop fail from earlier this year with the release of their latest issue.

The cover of their annual comedy issue stars comedians Kate McKinnon, Issa Rae and Sarah Silverman, with the addition of a few extra limbs.

In the photo, Saturday Night Live actress McKinnon's leg is stretched unnaturally across Insecure creator Rae's lap. Despite having normal legs, Silverman has been given two extra hands - one placed on Rae's shoulder while also somehow planting one on the floor beneath the stage.

After releasing the cover, GQ issued an "apology" on their website.

"GQ would like to apologise to Kate McKinnon, Issa Rae, and Sarah Silverman for the egregious mistakes made in the process of creating the cover for our 2018 comedy issue, the latest in our pantheon of mostly annual love letters to the funniest humans we know. Our intention was to celebrate the three super-funny superstars, who are all that is smart and perceptive and riotous and necessary in comedy right now. We deeply regret that the results violated GQ's rigorous standards of editorial excellence and the laws of nature."

The cover is a hilarious parody of the 2018 Hollywood Issue of GQ's fellow Condé Nast publication, Vanity Fair, in which Reese Witherspoon appeared to have three legs and Oprah Winfrey had an extra hand.
title: GQ mocks Vanity Fair's photoshop fail with spoof cover
